Common Fundamental Analysis & Valuation Methods

3.1 üìä Earnings Per Share (EPS)

1. Definition and Formula

  • FormulaÔºö
  • Simple understanding: EPS represents the profit earned per share for shareholders.

2. Why is it Important?

  • EPS is the foundation for many valuation methods (such as P/E ratio).
  • High EPS indicates strong profitability.
  • Consistently growing EPS shows the company's profits are steadily expanding.

3. Usage

  • Investors often compare EPS with stock price to judge if a stock is "expensive" or "cheap".
  • Analyzing EPS trends is more important than a single year (e.g., has EPS grown year-over-year over the past 5 years?).

4. Industry Differences

  • Consumer Staples: EPS is stable but grows slowly.
  • Technology Industry: EPS may fluctuate significantly, but has higher growth potential.
  • Financial Industry: EPS is affected by interest rates and economic cycles.

3.2 üìà Earnings Growth Rate

1. Definition and Formula

  • FormulaÔºö
  • It represents the growth rate of the company's profits.

2. Why is it Important?

  • Determines the company's future value. Even if current profits are modest, high growth rate can make it a good investment.
  • PEG Ratio combines P/E with growth rate to judge if valuation is reasonable.

3. Usage

  • Growth companies (like Nvidia, Meta) typically attract investors with high growth rates.
  • Mature companies (like Coca-Cola) have lower growth rates but are more stable.

4. Industry Differences

  • Tech Stocks: Growth rate may be >20%, but volatile.
  • Consumer Staples: Growth rate typically <10%, but resilient.
  • Financial Industry: Growth rate is closely related to economic cycles and interest rate environment.

üìù Summary

  • EPS = profit per share ‚Üí reflects current profitability.
  • Earnings Growth Rate = profit growth speed ‚Üí reflects future growth potential.
  • When investing, look at both EPS level and growth rate trends.
  • üëâ Example: Nvidia has high EPS + fast growth ‚Üí high valuation is reasonable.
  • Coca-Cola has stable EPS + low growth ‚Üí suitable for defensive investment.

3.3a üìä Price-to-Earnings Ratio (P/E)

1. Definition and Formula

  • FormulaÔºö
  • Represents how much investors are willing to pay per share for each $1 of current earnings.

2. Why is it Important?

  • P/E is the most common valuation metric.
  • Can quickly judge if a company is "cheap" or "expensive".

3. Usage

  • Most suitable for mature industries and companies with stable profits.
  • If a company is losing money or profits fluctuate significantly, P/E is less accurate.

4. Industry Differences

  • Consumer Staples: P/E typically 15‚Äì25x.
  • Tech Growth Stocks: P/E may be 25‚Äì40x or even higher.
  • Banking/Finance: P/E is relatively low, typically 10‚Äì15x.

Advantages: Simple and intuitive, most common.

Disadvantages: P/E can be distorted when profits fluctuate significantly. Not suitable for companies losing money.

3.3b üìä Price-to-Book Ratio (P/B)

1. Definition and Formula

  • FormulaÔºö
  • Represents the multiple of stock price relative to the company's book value.

2. Why is it Important?

  • Reflects the market's recognition of the company's asset value.
  • If P/B < 1, it means the stock price may be below the company's book value (possibly undervalued, or the market thinks asset quality is poor).

3. Usage

  • Especially suitable for banks, insurance, real estate - asset-driven companies.
  • For light-asset tech companies, P/B has limited reference value.

4. Industry Differences

  • Banking: P/B typically 1‚Äì2x, high ROE banks command a premium.
  • Manufacturing/Cyclical Stocks: P/B typically 1‚Äì3x.
  • Tech/Platform Companies: P/B is relatively high, not suitable as sole valuation basis.

3.4 üìä PEG Ratio (Price/Earnings to Growth)

1. Definition and Formula

  • FormulaÔºö
  • Combines valuation with the company's earnings growth rate.

2. Why is it Important?

  • Looking at P/E alone, high-growth companies may seem "expensive"; PEG can measure if growth is worth the premium.
  • Generally, PEG ‚âà 1 is considered reasonable valuation.

3. Usage

  • Especially suitable for high-growth companies (like Nvidia, Meta, Google).
  • Used to compare growth and valuation matching within the same industry.

4. Industry Differences

  • Technology Industry: PEG often > 1, but still reasonable if growth rate is very high.
  • Consumer Staples: Low growth, PEG often > 2, indicating expensive valuation but stable.
  • Financial Industry: Growth related to economic cycles, PEG should be interpreted with macro environment.

3.5 Common Investor Misconceptions

  • ‚ùå Misconception 1: High P/E = must be expensive.
    • ‚Üí Correct: High-growth companies reasonably enjoy high P/E.
  • ‚ùå Misconception 2: DCF calculation gives accurate value.
    • ‚Üí Correct: DCF is very sensitive to growth rate and discount rate, it's a "range judgment", not a single answer.
  • ‚ùå Misconception 3: All industries can use the same valuation method.
    • ‚Üí Correct: Banks look at P/B, tech companies look at P/E + PEG, startups focus more on DCF assumptions.
